message_1: What is the pressure gradient required to drive a 10μL/min flow of water through a 50μm wide and 5μm tall rectangular channel in a lab-on-a-chip device? Assume water to be an incompressible fluid with a density of 1000 kg/m³ and a viscosity of 1 mPa·s at 25°C.
message_2:
To solve this problem, we will use the Hagen-Poiseuille equation for pressure drop in a rectangular microchannel. The equation is:

ΔP = (12μQL) / (w^3h)

where ΔP is the pressure drop, μ is the dynamic viscosity of the fluid, Q is the volumetric flow rate, L is the length of the channel, w is the width of the channel, and h is the height of the channel.

First, we need to convert the given values to SI units:

Flow rate (Q): 10 μL/min = 10 × 10^(-6) L/min × (1/60) min/s × 1000 cm³/L = 1.67 × 10^(-9) m³/s
Width (w): 50 μm = 50 × 10^(-6) m
Height (h): 5 μm = 5 × 10^(-6) m
Viscosity (μ): 1 mPa·s = 1 × 10^(-3) Pa·s

We are not given the length (L) of the channel, so we will express the pressure gradient (ΔP/L) in terms of L:

ΔP/L = (12μQ) / (w^3h)

Now, we can plug in the given values:

ΔP/L = (12 × 1 × 10^(-3) Pa·s × 1.67 × 10^(-9) m³/s) / ((50 × 10^(-6) m)³ × (5 × 10^(-6) m))

ΔP/L = (20.04 × 10^(-12) Pa·m) / (6.25 × 10^(-18) m^4)

ΔP/L = 3.2064 × 10^6 Pa/m

The pressure gradient required to drive a 10 μL/min flow of water through a 50 μm wide and 5 μm tall rectangular channel in a lab-on-a-chip device is approximately 3.21 × 10^6 Pa/m.
